body: @jcanizales

Craig / Julien:
- What does that error mean? (`Handshake failed with fatal error SSL_ERROR_SSL: error:100000f7:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER.`)
- How can the message be reworded so it's actionable?

I'm a bit confused by this:

[GRPCCall useInsecureConnectionsForHost:kHostAddress];

Are we using an insecure connection here instead of SSL? How does the
SSL code get triggered?

On Fri, Sep 9, 2016 at 8:36 PM, Jorge Canizales notifications@github.com
wrote:

Is your server written in Go? I found someone getting the same error message when calling the Go gRPC server: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7666
I don't see any discussion in 2 months; has this been solved or worked-around? Is there any reason that the issue is still needed?
Oh, has been solved...I'll close it.   thx
How was this solved? im getting this with version 1.0.2 objcective c  with 1.0.5 on go server
@YioMidd Same here, go 1.7.1 and swift 3, what is the solution???
@iamqizhao are you still Go-gRPC-guy?
gRPC ObjectiveC v1.1.0 has been released. Could you please give that a try?
The common denominator in these reports is the Go server, from which the error message is coming (see https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/8057#issuecomment-246786026 ).
I see. @menghanl is handling Go server now. He is going to take a look.

gRPC-go uses the go official tls package: https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/blob/master/credentials/credentials.go#L172

Could there be a mistake in the config?
@acoroian , @KanybekMomukeyev , do you have a way for @menghanl to reproduce and investigate? Neither https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7666 nor https://github.com/coreos/etcd/issues/5213 do.

@jcanizales on my side the issue was that the server was using a new elliptic curve certificate instead of using rsa. as soon as we used an rsa cert things started working correctly. Did not have to do anything on the client side.

@jcanizales , @menghanl , @muxi , @acoroian 
This is how i generate key and certificate

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Generate CA key:
openssl genrsa -des3 -out ca.key 4096

# Generate CA certificate:
openssl req -new -x509 -days 365 -key ca.key -out ca.crt

# Generate server key:
openssl genrsa -des3 -out server.key 4096

# Generate server signing request:
openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr

# Self-sign server certificate:
openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in server.csr -CA ca.crt -CAkey ca.key -set_serial 01 -out server.crt

# Remove passphrase from the server key:
openssl rsa -in server.key -out server.key

# Generate client key:
openssl genrsa -des3 -out client.key 4096

# Generate client signing request:
openssl req -new -key client.key -out client.csr

# Self-sign client certificate:
openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in client.csr -CA ca.crt -CAkey ca.key -set_serial 01 -out client.crt

# Remove passphrase from the client key:
openssl rsa -in client.key -out client.key
```

Starting grpc server

```
certFile   = flag.String("cert_file", "certfiles/server.crt", "The TLS cert file")
keyFile    = flag.String("key_file", "certfiles/server.key", "The TLS key file")

creds, err := credentials.NewServerTLSFromFile(*certFile, *keyFile)
lis, err = net.Listen("tcp", port)
if err != nil {
	log.Fatalf("failed to listen: %v", err)
}
grpcServer = grpc.NewServer(grpc.Creds(creds))
println("Listen on " + port + " with TLS")
```

Tested with Go GRPC client, everything is OK
```
creds, err := credentials.NewClientTLSFromFile("../certfiles/ca.crt", "localhost")
if err != nil {
	println("Failed to create TLS credentials %v", err)
}

conn, err := grpc.Dial(address, grpc.WithTransportCredentials(creds))
if err != nil {
	println("did not connect: %v", err)
}

defer conn.Close()
// Creates a new CustomerClient
client := pb.NewRentautomationServiceClient(conn)
```

Now trying with Swift/ObjectiveC 1.0.2 Client

```
if let certificateFilePath = Bundle.main.path(forResource: "ca", ofType: "crt") {
            GRPCCall.useTestCertsPath(certificateFilePath, testName: "localhost", forHost: kHostAddress)
        }

```
ERROR ON IOS CLIENT SIDE:

> error ==> Optional(Error Domain=io.grpc Code=14 "{"created":"@1486449289.295385000","description":"EOF","file":"/Users/kanybek/Desktop/rentautomation/Pods/gRPC-Core/src/core/lib/iomgr/tcp_posix.c","file_line":235,"grpc_status":14}" UserInfo={io.grpc.TrailersKey={
> }, io.grpc.HeadersKey={
> }, NSLocalizedDescription={"created":"@1486449289.295385000","description":"EOF","file":"/Users/kanybek/Desktop/rentautomation/Pods/gRPC-Core/src/core/lib/iomgr/tcp_posix.c","file_line":235,"grpc_status":14}})

ERROR ON SERVER GRPC SIDE:

> grpc: Server.Serve failed to complete security handshake from "192.168.0.22:50885": tls: first record does not look like a TLS handshake

Tried all available combinations of keys, no success: 
```
ca.crt
ca.key
client.crt
client.csr
client.key
server.crt
server.csr
server.key
```

Re @acoroian 
Thanks for the report. Yes, by default we don't support non-RSA cipher suites on the C core side. We should probably add ECDHE_ECDSA support for this stack.
@KanybekMomukeyev that looks like a different error than what @YioMidd was getting.
I am experiencing this problem with Nuget.exe trying to establish an ssl connection from Linux, apparently using mono. Any ideas?
Hey @jboeuf, will #9630 fix this?
I don't know about the specific problem from @Jose-CF (I have no indication that it is the same lack of ECDSA certs support) but yes, #9630 will fix the issue for @acoroian.

@jcanizales  I am also getting the same error with gRPC (Release 1.8.2).

`E1228 09:48:55.611283000 123145401966592 ssl_transport_security.cc:976] Handshake failed with fatal error SSL_ERROR_SSL: error:100000f7:SSL routines:OPENSSL_internal:WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER.`

My server is written in Java and Client is in Objective-C.

I am using Xcode, Objective-C and gRPC to make an RPC call to an AWS EC2 server. 
I am not sure what is causing this error.
-  Do I need some kind of SSL certificate in my Xcode Project to talk to a remote server?
Is the issue above still active? The problem is usually observed when you are not using the newest release.

The error message is a bit misleading; from my experience quite a few issues end up showing this message. The best thing to do is to get some grpc trace logs (with [environment variables](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/doc/environment_variables.md)) and analyze some more verbose error messages in there.

Took the latest  
 pod 'SwiftGRPC' 
 pod 'SwiftProtobuf'
version using pod update and it got fixed .

Installing BoringSSL 10.0.6 (was 10.0.5 and source changed to `https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git` from `https://github.com/cocoapods/specs.git`)
Installing SwiftGRPC 0.5.1 (was 0.4.3 and source changed to `https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git` from `https://github.com/cocoapods/specs.git`)
Installing gRPC-Core 1.12.0 (was 1.11.0 and source changed to `https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git` from `https://github.com/cocoapods/specs.git`)
Installing Realm 3.7.6 (was 3.7.4 and source changed to `https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git` from `https://github.com/cocoapods/specs.git`)
Installing RealmSwift 3.7.6 (was 3.7.4 and source changed to `https://github.com/CocoaPods/Specs.git` from `https://github.com/cocoapods/specs.git`)

Then all i need was create the session/service with my certificate.

let certPath = Bundle.main.url(forResource: "XYZ", withExtension: "pem")!
        let certificate = try! String(contentsOf: certPath)
        service = Pronounce_PronounceServiceClient(address: Constants.ServerApi.grpcBaseUrl, certificates: certificate)
